alternative to the honor system. The proposal now being

responsibility for the conduct of exams where it rightfully
belongs—in the hands of the individual faculty members,
though pains have been taken to insure that students share in
the duty of preventing cheating.

structure. Under it, students and faculty would be allowed,
though not required, to take preventative measures. The
apparatus for dealing with special circumstances is now ready
at hand. We urge that the proposal be given fair consideration
by the Student Council and, if it is approved there, the
backing of the student body. The committee has found a
wide consensus, on the student and faculty levels, that
something must be done to confront the cheating problem
which is surfacing not only at Hopkins, but at most other
colleges and universities in the country.
The document we have waited (and waited!) for is finally
at hand.

compromise
It seems that at last someone has come up with a palatable
alternative to the honor system. The proposal now being
completed by the student-faculty committee headed by
Professor Owen Phillips represents the long-awaited
compromise between the honor system and mandated
proctoring.
Though the modification of the honor system is a painful
step to accept, we feel that the panel's proposal is an
intelligent measure which takes into account, as Phillips and
other have pointed out, that the problems currently plaguing
the honor system are temporary. The proposal places
responsibility for the conduct of exams where it rightfully
belongs—in the hands of the individual faculty members,
though pains have been taken to insure that students share in
the duty of preventing cheating.
Perhaps the proposal's strongest point, though, is its loose
structure. Under it, students and faculty would be allowed,
